title-group.article-title: The Behavior of Electric Utility Common Stock Prices near the Ex-Dividend Date

abstract.p: This paper shows that the relatively high yields that electric utility common stocks afford are attractive to two different classes of investors: taxable institutions seeking short-term gains and long-term investors seeking a regular income flow. In the first case, taxable institutions that can claim the 85% dividends received deduction buy the stock before the ex-dividend date and hold it just long enough to qualify for the deduction, which leads to a pattern of abnormal buying pressure just before the ex-dividend date and abnormal selling pressure just after. In the second case, long-term investors in electric utility common stocks generally prefer dividends over capital gains.
